III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and behavioral
health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A is handicapped and had blood coming from the right tear
duct and was sent home from school. Youth A has had pain in
their buttocks and will need to walk around because of it. Youth A
has pain when going to the bathroom and a consistent phlegmy
cough. Youth A has hearing aids and a large wax build-up and
odor from the ears. Youth A will pull on their ears to hear better.
The facility has been recommended to seek medical care, but it is
unknown if they have done so.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the school on 1/31/25
in coordination with MDHHS Worker. Youth A had a
stuffy/runny nose, his right eye was a little red, and he sat fine on
the chair without showing any signs of pain. Youth A reported he
has allergies often, so he gets a stuffy nose a lot. Youth A
reported he feels fine and doesn’t feel sick. Youth A reported he
hasn’t been to the doctor recently and could not remember the
date of his last doctor’s appointment. Youth A reported his ears,
eyes, butt, and entire body felt fine. Youth A reported he was not
feeling any pain anywhere and did not have any complaints or
concerns. Youth A reported a long time ago he had a bump on his
butt, and it hurt bad, but it’s been gone for a while. Youth A
reported when it happened, staff took him to the doctor. Youth A
reported sometimes when he has a bowel movement it hurts, and
it stretches his skin too much. Youth A reported he went to the
doctor for this when his butt bled one time, and the doctor
reported he ripped some tissue. Youth A reported he always
receives medicine from the doctor if there’s a problem, and staff at
the facility always give him his medicine. Youth A reported when
his ears hurt, he lets staff know and they give him medicine. Youth
A reported he has medicine for his eye too. Youth A reported his
eye was not bleeding yesterday at school and he’s not sure why
they said it was. Youth A reported he loves living at the facility,
feels safe there, and feels the staff take really good care of him.
Para-pro was interviewed face to face at the school on 1/31/25
in coordination with MDHHS Worker. Para-pro reported she is
Youth A’s one-on-one Para-pro at school. Her opinion is Youth A
2

is being neglected in his current placement. Para-pro reported
Youth A comes to school all the time looking like no one helps him
take care of his face (crusty boogers, sore on chin he picks all the
time, ears always full of wax). Para-pro reported Youth A’s
appearance isn’t one of someone who is being taken care of
properly. Para-pro reported Youth A pulls his ears down all the
time because he can’t hear well. Para-pro reported Youth A has
hearing aids so she thinks he can’t hear well because of the
amount of wax in his ears. Para-pro reported Youth A was sent
home yesterday because he had blood coming out of his eye.
Para-pro reported Youth A complains his butt hurts all the time, so
they have extra cushions for him to sit on and he has to walk
around frequently because it hurts to sit. Para-pro reported she is
not sure if the pain on his butt is from a medical situation or a
result of abuse, but it’s been a concern the entire school year thus
far. Para-pro then reported Youth A has not complained about
pain in his butt since before Christmas break. Para-pro reported
Youth A will always complain he’s hungry. Para-pro reported she’s
repeatedly asked the facility to take Youth A to the doctor. Para-
pro admitted she’s never followed up with the facility to ask if they
took Youth A to the doctor or the outcome of any doctor’s visits.
Para-pro admitted she is not familiar with his medical diagnoses or
genetic condition and isn’t sure what the chronic symptoms or
treatments of his diagnoses or condition are. Para-pro reported
she knows the information is on file with the school somewhere.
Secretary was interviewed face to face at the school on
1/31/25 in coordination with MDHHS Worker. Secretary
reported she is the lead secretary at Youth A’s school. Secretary
reported the concerns listed in the allegations are valid. Secretary
reported Youth A has a hearing impairment and his ears are
frequently dirty. Secretary reported Youth A has been complaining
about his butt hurting for months. Secretary reported a few months
ago, Youth A told her he “had a hold in his butt” and she assumed
that must mean he had hemorrhoids. Secretary reported Youth A
then complained his butt was bleeding, and she assumed he must
have been constipated or straining too much when having a bowel
movement. Secretary reported she thinks the last time he
complained about any pain on his butt was before Christmas.
Secretary reported Youth A went home yesterday because his eye
was bleeding. Secretary reported she knows he has a medical
condition but was not sure if the issue with his eye was related or
not. Secretary reported Youth A has called home more often this
year compared to last year, and she cannot tell if he’s always
having ailments or if he is having a harder time with his
schoolwork this year. Secretary reported she’s talked to the facility
3

about taking Youth A to the doctor to address his ailments.
Secretary admitted she’s never asked the facility about any
medical appointments he’s gone to or followed-up to find out what
treatment he receives. Secretary reported Case Manager is
amazing with Youth A and seems to care about him a lot.
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed face to face at the
facility on 1/31/25 in coordination with MDHHS Worker. CA
reported when the school called yesterday to report Youth A had
blood in his eye, Case Manager heard Youth A yelling in the
background saying, “there’s not blood in my eye!”. CA reported
when Youth A got home that day, he did not have any blood in his
eye, but his eye was red. CA reported Youth A’s eye drops and
eye creams are applied daily due to his chronic eye problems
because of his Kaufman’s syndrome diagnosis. CA reported
Youth A has frequent build-up of fluid and wax in his ears because
of Kaufman’s syndrome and requires an irrigation system to clean
his ears. CA reported sometimes the irrigation system doesn’t get
it all, or it builds up quicker during the day when they can’t irrigate
his ears because he’s at school. CA reported Youth A’s ears
cannot be cleaned with a Q-tip because he has very tight ear
canals. CA reported Youth A’s doctor instructed them to bring
Youth A to the doctor if the wax build-up gets to be too much or
causes him pain. CA reported Youth A is good about telling them
when he’s in pain or something else is going on with his body, and
he hasn’t complained about his ears at all. CA reported Youth A
went to the doctor a few months ago because he tore some tissue
when he had a hard bowel movement. CA reported Youth A was
prescribed some ointment and it healed. CA reported all of the
concerns mentioned in the allegations either haven’t happened
(ear odor and blood from his eye), were addressed by the doctor
as soon as they occurred (pain in buttocks and pain when using
the bathroom), or are because of his diagnosis of Kaufman’s
syndrome (consistent phlegmy cough, eye issues, ear wax build-
up, hearing aids).
Licensee Designee (LD) was interviewed face to face at the
facility on 1/31/25 in coordination with MDHHS Worker. LD
reported Youth A sees an ENT through UofM. LD reported Youth
A is good about telling staff if he’s in pain, has a complaint about
his health, or needs anything. LD reported Youth A hugs her all
the time which puts her close to his ears, and she’s never noticed
an odor.
Case Manager (CM) was interviewed via phone on 2/27/25 in
coordination with MDHHS Worker. CM reported she has been
4

Youth A’s case manager since January 2024, and she is
responsible for managing most of his appointments. CM reported
if Youth A complains of any pain or if there are any noticeable
ailments or illnesses, CM is responsible for scheduling the
appointment and taking Youth A to address it. CM reported
sometimes it takes a day for a doctor’s appointment to be
scheduled with the primary care physician, so if it’s an urgent
concern she will take Youth A to urgent care. CM reported the
pain on Youth A’s buttocks was due to two different issues. One of
the issues was Youth A had a boil on his butt cheek, which
caused him pain when sitting, so he had a cushion to sit on at
school. CM reported Youth A was prescribed medication for the
boil and had a follow-up appointment to address it. CM reported
the other issue was when he tore some tissue due to having a
hard bowel movement. CM reported Youth A was prescribed
ointment, and it healed without follow-up. CM reported Youth A is
diagnosed with Kaufman’s syndrome, and eye crust, nose
crust/boogers, and ear fluid/wax build-up are some chronic
symptoms of his condition. CM reported sometimes the ear
fluid/wax builds up more during the school day because the
vinegar irrigation staff at the facility can do, cannot be done at the
school. CM reported the school nurse has all the information
regarding Youth A’s condition, medications, etc. on file. CM
reported she has never noticed an odor coming from Youth A’s
ear before. CM reported Youth A has never had blood coming
from his eye. CM reported when she got a call from the school
yesterday stating Youth A was bleeding from his eye, she heard
Youth A yelling in the background that his eye was just red, and it
was not bleeding. CM reported when she got to the school to pick
Youth A up, his eye was only red and was not bleeding. CM
reported she took Youth A back to the facility, wiped his eyes with
a warm washcloth, applied the ointment and drops, and then
Youth A was fine. CM reported the only time Youth A has ever
complained about any hearing issues is when his hearing aid
batteries are dying, but he is quick to let staff know so they can
change the batteries. CM reported the school also has an extra
set of batteries in case the batteries are low during school hours.
CM reported she has never seen Youth A pull on his ears. CM
reported she checks Youth A’s ears daily to see if there is too
much build-up, and if there is, she will do the irrigation. CM
reported Youth A is really good about letting staff know if he is in
pain or uncomfortable, so they’re able to address any issues
quickly.
5

DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Email from Youth A’s Foster Care Worker (FCW) dated
1/31/25 states she was not aware of any of the concerns
listed in the allegations. She notes she has seen Youth A
the last two months and he has not identified any of the
problems listed in the allegations. She notes Youth A has
ongoing health issues, including Kaufman’s Syndrome and
recurrent ear infections.
• Email from CA dated 2/4/25 notes the following:
o Rectal concerns: Youth A was seen by the doctor for
a cutaneous abscess on his right buttocks on
9/13/24. At the appointment, Youth A was negative
for constipation. Youth A was prescribed an
antibiotic and scheduled for a one-week follow-up.
Antibiotic was passed for a full 7 days and was seen
for a follow-up appointment on 9/20/24. On 10/3/24,
CA reported they received a phone call from the
school stating Youth A said he saw bright red blood
when he tried to have a bowel movement. CA
transported Youth A to the doctor for an
examination. At the appointment, Youth A was
prescribed Docusate Sodium 2x daily for 14 days
and Hydrocortisone cream 2x daily. Follow-up was
not required by the physician and no further
concerns were reported by anyone, including Youth
A, afterwards.
o ENT concerns: Youth A was taken to University of
Michigan on 7/9/24 for an ear appointment. The
doctor cleaned Youth A’s ears and recommended
the facility continue with vinegar irrigations and using
a warm washcloth to wipe out crust as needed.
• Youth A’s medical documentation notes he is diagnosed
with bilateral deafness, exposure keratitis, gastrostomy
tube in place, irregular astigmatism – bilateral, Kaufman
oculocerebrofacial syndrome, mild protein – calorie
malnutrition, Myopia of both eyes, Nasolacrimal duct
obstruction – congenital, oral aversion, Ptosis (droopy
eyelids) – bilateral, chronic bacterial otitis externa (left), and
conductive hearing loss of left ear with unrestricted hearing
of right ear.
• National Library of Medicine (www.nih.gov) notes Kaufman
oculocerebrofacial syndrome is characterized by
developmental delay, severe intellectual ability, and
6

distinctive craniofacial features. Most affected youth have
feeding issues, ocular abnormalities, hearing impairment,
and respiratory tract abnormalities.
• Youth A was seen for the following medical appointments
since June 2024:
o 6/13/24 – Seen for hearing check-up & no concerns
noted.
o 8/28/24 – Seen for well-child exam. Recommended
starting acetic acid ear irrigation as recommended
by UofM ENT. No concerns noted.
o 9/13/24 – Seen for painful bump on buttocks. Pain
started 4-5 days prior, but thought it was an ingrown
hair. Pain became worse and bump became bigger,
so medical attention was sought. Diagnosed with
Cutaneous abscess of buttock & prescribed
Cephalexin 3x daily for 7 days. Follow-up in 7 days.
o 9/20/24 – Seen for follow-up & no concerns noted.
o 10/3/24 – Seen for rectal bleeding due to painfully
hard bowel movement. Diagnosed with a tender 1
cm posterior anal fissure – no masses or
hemorrhoids seen. Prescribed medications – no
follow-up required.
o 1/31/25 – Seen for a check-up due to this
investigation & no concerns were noted.
• Youth A’s Medication Administration Records from August
2024-January 2025 were reviewed and no concerns were
noted.
• Multidisciplinary Report from KRESA dated 10/11/23 notes
Youth A has chronic otorrhea (persistent discharge of fluid
from the ear that lasts for more than six weeks) and narrow
ear canals. Youth A has been seen by UofM ENT for
removal of earwax under anesthesia before.
• Medical and Dental Care Policy states LTAI will ensure
each youth receives routine and non-routine medical care
as required. When a youth requires medical care, LTAI staff
will ensure the youth is promptly transported to the
appropriate healthcare facility to have their medical needs
addressed in a timely and efficient manner.
• CM does not have any disciplinary records listed in her
employee file. CM was trained on the facility’s medical care
policy on 8/12/24.
7

Analysis The facility is found in compliance as per interviews conducted
and documentation reviewed, Youth A’s medical needs have been
appropriately addressed.
• According to interviews conducted with CA and CM, Youth
A reported he did not have blood coming from his right tear
duct.
• Youth A had pain in his buttocks in September 2024 and
October 2024 due to two separate medical issues. Youth A
received appropriate medical assessment and prescribed
medications. Youth A has not had any issues with his
buttocks since that time.
• Youth A has a consistent phlegmy cough, hearing aids, and
large wax/fluid build-up in his ears due to his medical
diagnosis of Kaufman’s Syndrome. These are all chronic
conditions which are being treated by the University of
Michigan’s ENT department as well as Youth A’s primary
care physician. According to staff at the facility, they have
not noticed Youth A pulling on his ears to hear better.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
